reviewText: Great cast, pleasantly surprised at how well this movie was done. A family of thinkers, some far advanced for their age, which isnt always a good thing. The casting was great and believable. There are some sad moments of reality but in the end, you're left feeling somewhat satisfied. Not all happy endings are perfect, it's all really relative. This movie plays on the decisions we make based on emotions and the familiarity that stunts your growth from difficult situations. The ending felt a bit rushed, not too believable, but satisfying either way. I would give it 3.5 stars. The cast made this movie more so than the subject material.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: What a movie should be.....a believable story with wonderful characters played by fabulous actors.  My entire family LOVED this movie.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Several underlying plots merge together to create a great, albeit bubble-gummy, series of love stories that come together wonderfully in the end.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: I wanted to love this film.  Greg Kinnear is one of my favorite actors.  I had several issues with the movie, though (in no particular order):1.  So many parts of the movie were unbelievable.  The father is a writer who hasn't had anything published in over 2 years, yet he lives in a sprawling 3-story beachhouse.  His wife left him 3 years ago, but he thinks she'll return, so he still sets a place for her at the dinner table every night.  Really?!  He also goes to her new house and peeks in her windows.  Are we supposed to find that endearing rather than just plain creepy?His kids are both writers.  The 23 year old daughter is published, and the 16 year old wrote a piece that was so awe-inspiring that Stephen King called him on the phone and said he loved it.  Yeah, right.  The daughter is a cynical b*tch who tells a young man at a bar how he has absolutely no chance of ever dating her because she doesn't believe in love.  But she finds out his mom is dying of cancer and all of a sudden she falls in love with him.The mom spends more than half the movie telling the dad that he needs to get over her, that she will never take him back.  But then on Thanksgiving day, the doorbell at his house rings and...you guessed it....the mom is there asking for another chance.  Good thing he's been setting a place for her at the table for 3 years.  Cue the sappy music.2.  The film was slow.  Many times I was tempted to fast-forward.  At times I found myself checking my e-mail while watching it.3.  Too many plotlines:  The marriage problems with the mom and dad, the son's girlfriend who has a drug problem, the daughter who is afraid to fall in love, the daughter's book being published caused son to be envious, the neighbor who jogs over to the dad's house daily to have sex with him, the daughter's boyfriend's mom dying of cancer.  Too much was crammed into a single movie.All in all, it wasn't a horrible movie, but not one that I certainly recommend.
summary: Slow, unbelievable, predictable and too many storylines.....
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Thank God I only rented this. Had to turn it off half way through. One of those movies where you were still p.o. because you got sucked in by the trailers.
summary: Could of been worse could of purchased it
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Funny and sometimes sad family drama. Family life isn't always perfect and this is about that. Shows that love isn't a fairytale.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Good cast. Some good acting. Somewhat of a good story. I found some of the situations and circumstances to be a bit too contrived to be believable. While the underlying familial issues and dysfunction are obviously true-to-life, the writer does push credulity with regards to the contexts in which these issues and dysfunction emerge. For example, the daughter/writer character is way too cynical, streetwise, and worldly to be believable. Has she really experienced so much of life at the age of 22-23, that she can speak with such authority, wisdom and disrespect to her peers and her parents? I don't think so. Which makes the fact that she's written not one, but two publishable books an even greater stretch. To the writer's credit, this character undergoes a transformation-thankfully, which in the context of film, provides a dramatic turn. However, the denouement of her turn rests on another implausible and complicated situation based on the infidelity trail of her parents. Huh? This family is a mess--and that part of the story is very real and true-to-life.
summary: Mixed results for this family in crisis tale.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie.  I hadn't heard of it before I saw it here on Amazon, and I was really surprised that I enjoyed it as much as I did.  The acting and the storyline was realistic and endearing. This movie focuses on building new relationships and rebuilding old ones, between siblings, ex-husband/ex-wife, parents with their son/daughter, and new lovers/friends.  It gives you a sense of hope, without being too unrealistic.  And at the end of it, it gives you an overall good feeling, and personally, I enjoy those types of movies the most.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: My wife and I enjoy quirky movies. This movie was described as such and sounded promising. There was nothing close to quirky here. This is the sad tale of a family trying to find its way after the devastating disaster of a divorce. The movie is honest. The emotions are raw and true as far as I can tell. The acting is well-done. I liked all the members of the family and at the same time, I found them to be unlikeable, self-centered and shallow. So, would I recommend this movie. Yes, because it is good, well-written and well-acted. But it is not quirky.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: But hey a I really enjoyed it. The characters were interesting and the plot though a tad implausible was not boring.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Someone once said "You cannot dictate to something its nature." It is what it is and we are who we are. For my dollar that's what this movie was about.Here's the scoop. Bill Borgens (Greg Kinnear) is an award winning author. His 17 daughter is publishing her first novel and his son is writing poems and short stories. The daughter is promiscuous. She holds all men at arms length and uses them strictly for sexual gratification. The son has a thing for a girl with real baggage, He figures his love will get her to shake some of that baggage. Dad is divorced and waiting for his ex to reconsider. He figures he'll hold tight and one day she'll realize her mistake and return. Can these folks find their way in the world?I guess you could call this and Indy flick but with Kinnear, Jennifer Connelly, Lily Collins and Kristen Bell in attendance this is a bit closer to Hollywood than to Indy. I did enjoy it but it all seemed so obvious. And the need for the director/writer/producers to wrap it up so nice and neat at the end really irked me. Life is not art and art is not life but this could have (should have) been much more subtle. All these people trying to change those around them and all with a specific character framed from specific incidents just didn't ring true. I liked much of the dialogue and it was dotted with some nifty Indy tunes from the likes of Bon Iver and the National. It was nicely (subtly) shot and edited. It was all handled well but it suffered from a script that was too self aware.I can't tell someone to avoid this movie because, for all its faults, it was a pleasant view. I liked the characters and all did well in their roles. Just don't set your hopes too high.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: too slow, and some part difficult to understand,too much going on at the same time...but it is only my opinion
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: The movie is a bit of a love story but it is also so much more. What I love about this movie is that it does a superb job illustrating the human condition. I have probably watched the movie ten times this year so far. The reason that I love the movie so much is that it marvelously runs through the whole gambit of human emotions and makes you want to laugh in some parts and laugh in others. The movie has such a quality and evokes such a positive emotional response that it makes me feel very human, and happy to do so. I think the quote from  Raymond Carver that is used in the movie more than adequately explains the main theme of the movie: "I could hear my heart beating. I could hear everyone's heart. I could hear the human noise we sat there making, not one of us moving, not even when the room went dark."
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: This is a fabulous story of an intellectual high IQ yet broken family over the course of a year. I love the premise, the interior design, fashion, and education level of this liberal movie. All around superb story telling at its finest. I even shed a happy tear at the end. Highly recommended to audiences 13 and over who enjoy the functions and dysfunctions of a modern family as they realize themselves.
summary: Beauiful landscape, intellectual style, class, sophistication.

reviewText: I absolutely loved this movie. Everything about it was real, believable, and highly entertaining. I definitely recommend you watch this immediately!
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: I am the biggest movie critic out there, and this one I loved. The characters were authentic, and that is hard to capture. The acting and directing were flawless...you just knew these people, they were very real.I thought the story was great. Poignant. I saw a reviewer say it was not complex, and that person obviously does not know about love and loss and reconciliation.Best of all, it has a great ending. I loved it!A writer/director made it...such talent! And a single vision. Films suck because of too many people with too many visions. Good job! Kudos!There is a lot of bad language and drug use by teens. I guess I overlooked those things because of the richness of the story and the characters. I wouldn't want a teen to see this or even a YA, it does require some maturity to separate these offensive elements. I still think it was poignant---the scene where he is watching his ex-wife through the window was done so perfectly. A subtle hand, which I like.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: I thought the acting was well done by everyone.  Some of the premise was far-fetched like the kids' writing success.  I thought Kate's drug problem was not well-developed and the separation between the mom and dad was also vague and unexplained.  The glib attitude towards sex was not a good message.  I do like how they stuck together and worked through things, and for the most part, love prevailed.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: This is a very good movie. I see a lot of ok movies these days but they're so rarely entertaining along the lines of Family Stone, Blue Jasmine, etc. I'm not a movie critic so this will be short. Stuck in Love has a little bit of everything but it delivers where it's most crucial - we care about the characters. I wouldn't say this is as good as The Family Stone but I will say it reminded me of it and that's one of my favorites. I highly recommend this movie - the actors across the board just deliver. First movie I've seen in months that I can happily say I'll watch again.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: I rented this movie one Saturday while cleaning the house and was surprised that I like it so much that I sat down on the couch and watched the entire film. The situations were realistic and the acting was great. Divorce is never easy and that coupled with the coming-of-age story of the son and the troubled mother-daughter relationship could have made for a trite and boring moving. Fortunately, the story was well-written and contained several heart-fealt scenes that set the film apart. I really enjoyed it.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: You know, after the first 10 minutes of this particular movie, I was not sure I was going to like this movie. But Readers stay calm. Stuck In Love Is a movie to watch.Meet Bill (Greg Kinnear): Bill is a well known author and father of two. Samantha( Lily Collins) is Bill's daughter also a writer like her dad. Rusty, (Nat Wolff) is Bill's son and also writes from time to time.The story in this movie is dramatic thanks to the many great performances by each individual actor. Each emotion the character in Stuck In Love has whether it be: happiness, sadness, loneliness, etc. you feel it right with the character. Watching this movie reminded me of why movies like Perks of Being a Wallflower, even The Descendants hit home when I watch them. The situations present in this movie feel real and are actually relatable for myself believe it or not. I will not call Stuck In Love absolutely amazing or super terrific, but it is definitely one of this years independent films that is well acted, well sequenced and very well scripted. Glad to have watched this movie.4 StarsSupporting Cast: Jennifer Connelly, Logan Lerman, Kristin Bell, and a Surprise phone call from a world famed Novelist
summary: As a Fellow Reviewer, and movie person, this one should not be missed
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.As human beings, we look at love as this all-important feeling that dictates our happiness. However, in reality, love is an unfair and complex concept that isn't easily accessible. There are people who go their entire life without finding "the one" and there are others who seem to hit the jackpot on their first try. Still, even after all the heartbreak and all the suffering, most never give up hope. It should come as no surprise that love is a constant topic in the rich-indie Stuck In Love, but there's definitely more to it than that.Stuck In Love follows the Borgens family, a complex group of individuals with a huge passion for the literary arts. Bill Borgens (Greg Kinnear) is a novelist who's been struggling for three years after his wife Erica (Jennifer Connelly) left him. While together, Bill and Erica birthed two children; Sam (Lily Collins) and Rusty (Nat Wolff). The former is in college and is in the process of getting her first novel published. The latter, on the other hand, is a high school student who suffers from a lack of life experience. While Bill, Sam, and Rusty may each be going through their own personal issues, there is this unbreakable bond between the three of them due to their love of writing.The unique thing about this film isn't necessarily its story, but in the way that story is told. Because these three family members are living very different lives, they aren't always going to be in the same room together. Instead, the narrative is strategically organized so we follow each individual separately. For the most part, the story follows Rusty, then Bill, then Sam, and the ending ties them together. When it was all said and done, it was clear that each of them had experienced their own personal transformation and it was the result of everything we witnessed them go through.In fact, what I found most impressive about Stuck In Love was this character development. For example, at the beginning of the film Sam is very cynical about love and she considers herself to be a "realist." However, by the end of the story she does a complete 180. Part of this is due to her meeting Lou (Logan Lerman) and part of it is due to her learning new information about her parents' relationship. It was amazing to see such a huge change that felt both natural and genuine. No matter who you are, there are going to be events that are going to alter the way you think, and I believe this film did a wonderful job of showing that.Another thing I really loved was the way the actors made you connect with their characters. Specifically Collins and Lerman, who probably have the two most emotionally unstable characters from the entire cast. Both Sam and Lou are struggling with some heavy issues that go beyond the simplicity of Bill and Rusty's problems. Now that's not to say their problems aren't significant, but Sam and Lou's are more grand in their scope. One is suffering with severe trust issues while the other has a very ill mother. In the end, I think this is what allows the audience to connect on a deeper level and it allows these individuals to feel more three dimensional.That's not to say the film is perfect, though. The way the story is structured results in the film feeling a bit uneven and unfocused. There were times where I was watching one thing unfold, but then we jumped to another character and it broke the flow of the actual story. Also, some of the characters -- like Kate (Liana Liberato), Rusty's love interest -- were severely underdeveloped. This is another individual who seems to be going through a really tough time, but the writers never do much to expand beyond just telling you what's wrong with her. I also would have liked to have seen more from Lou, but he at least felt fleshed out in comparison to Kate.Finally, as a whole, the cast was very enjoyable. During some of the more emotional scenes things did get a little rocky, but there weren't many of those so it didn't hinder the experience too much. Also, I personally felt that each character was perfectly cast. Even the minor roles like Tricia (Kristen Bell) and Jason (Spencer Breslin) -- when was the last time you saw him in something? -- were flawless. In fact, I think this is one of my favorite roles from Bell. She may not have had a lot of screen-time, but her character was so... spunky.Overall Score: 7.9/10 - Stuck In Love is far from perfect, but it's still very enjoyable. It has a nice cast of characters and the story is well thought out, but it is a bit uneven and some of these characters could have used some more attention. With that said, though, I really enjoyed it and I think there's a lot to love if you choose to give it a chance.
Title: Stuck in Love

Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Is anyone else tired of watching movies about dysfunctional families where the parents act "cool' by allowing their children to smoke pot, drink alcohol, toss around "F Bombs", and discuss their sex lives? Apparently that is the Hollywood film industry's version of sophisticated, hip parents instead of the reality where those kind of horrible parents would be turned into social services!I found no redeeming characters in this lame film except for Louis, who is mocked by his girlfriend for having ideals and family values. The girlfriend played by Lily Collins was just vile, and I got the distinct impression that she is fairly close to that character in real life. The other thing that puzzled me in this film was the fact that Jennifer Connelly was trotted out yet again as the stunning, unattainable ideal of womanhood, as she is in so many films; I find her quite average-looking and anorexic, myself.This movie is billed as a romantic comedy, while I found nothing funny here. It's just a run-of-the-mill drama with a few sweet moments thrown in. (On a side note, Patrick Schwarzenegger has a small role in this film, which clearly his parents helped him get. He is no great shakes as an actor, and his entire part was to utter several "F Bombs" and shove a girl to the ground. I hope his mother Maria inspires him to be better than that in real life, as his father isn't exactly a role model.) Anyway there is nothing to be learned or gained by watching this film, and I'm sorry I wasted my time on it.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: MINI REVIEW: Director/writer Boone's semi-autobiographical tale of an established writer trying to win his ex-wife back but overlapping with a variety of subplots of various types of love between his children and others. Boasts an all star cast with believable and mostly likable actors that in the end gives you a Hollywood ending towards most of the romances which some cynical Americans will despise. Rampant themes about love, holding on to hopeless dreams, forgiveness, curing old wounds and opening yourself up to life experiences to become a better writer. Yes, that was Stephen King on the phone.Lily Collins nailed several of her scenes. Also starring Greg Kinnear, Kirsten Bell, Logan Lerman, Nat Wolff and Jennifer Connelly.OVERALL GRADE: B plus to A minus.
summary: MY GRADE: B plus to A minus.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: No matter how hard I tried, I absolutely couldn't care less what happened to any of these six characters.  Are we really expected to believe both teenage children of a famous author have published works of their own?  It's absurd.  They show no signs of the maturity, work ethic, or even life experience it would require to be great writers.  The worst moment was a personal call from Stephen King to the 16 year old to tell him how awesome his story was...as if they weren't all bloated and self important enough.  All the crises felt contrived and the musical cues insisted upon themselves in an overly obvious way.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: "Stuck In Love" (2013 release; 96 min.) brings the story of the Borgens family. As the movie opens, we see Bill Borgens (played by Greg Kinnear) secretly looking inside the house of his ex-wife Erica (played by Jennifer Connelly), who left him a few years ago to marry a younger guy. We learn that Bill still isn't over Erica, and is "stuck in love". We also meet their daughter Sam (played by Lily Collins), a college student who somehow managed to publish a novel with a major publishing house, and hence following in the footsteps of her dad. Sam is all tough on the outside when it comes to love and relationships. Then there is their son Rusty, a HS kid who also aspires to become a writer and who has a crush on Kate, a seemingly unavailable girl in his class. Lastly, we get to know Tricia (played by Kirsten Bell), Bill's occasional girlfriend, and who is trying to coach Bill back into the dating scene. Will Bill and Erica get back together again? or will Bill find success in the dating scene? or both? will Rusty win the love of Kate? and what about the toughness of Sam? To tell you more would ruin your viewing pleasure of this plot-heavy movie, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.Couple of comments: this is the feature debut of writer-director Josh Boone, who brings us a pleasant rom-com, even if at times it's played too safe in my opinion. In fact, the movie stands out for me for the acting performances. I almost always enjoy Greg Kinnear, and likewise for Jennifer Connelly, and I did here again. But the bigger surprise here is Lily Collins (daughter of Genesis singer Phil Collins). When she makes her first appearance in the movie, I thought for a second or two "wow, Jennifer Connelly looks so young!", only to then realize it was not Connelly, but Collins does in fact looks like a replica of Connelly 20 years ago. And it's not just the looks, as Collins carries a big part of the movie on her shoulders, and with ease. We surely have not seen the last of her (she also stars in the upcoming "The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones" in a few weeks). Last but certainly not least, the movie features a great soundtrack of indie music, scored by Mike Mogis and Nathaniel Walcott (from Bright Eyes), with some new songs and also a few older from Bright Eyes and others (at one point one of the HS kids gives a Bright Eyes CD as a Christmas gift--do teenagers really still buy CDs?).Bottom line: take this movie for what it is: a pleasant rom-com that is as utterly predictable (as to the plot) as it is enjoyable (as to the performances). This movie showed up last weekend at my local art-house theatre here in Cincinnati without any pre-release hype or advertising. I figured this won't play very long so I went to see it today. The screening that I attended was attended okay, but certainly was not packed. If you find yourself in the mood at some point for a lighter and pleasant film where you don't get challenged whatsoever and all the work is being done for you on the screen, go ahead and check out "Stuck In Love", be it in the theatre or on DVD.
summary: 3.5 stars... as utterly predicatble as it is enjoyable
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Greg Kinnear excels in this movie as he often does in family crisis films. I like that it is about a family of writers. The little cameo of Stephen King's voice on the phone was an added perk. oh yes Kinnear's character is still stuck on his wife but if yer gonna call it predictable that's kind of ridiculous because there are only two options she comes back to him or she doesn't. That's a 50/50 choice unless she gets run down by a car..Oh how cutting edge.(being sarcastic) The movie centers a lot on how much the divorce damaged these children and that is an important message. The thing is how much you feel their pain  through such excellent acting. Well I liked it and 4 stars .
summary: Stuck In Love Gets You Stuck On This Movie!
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: This film had such promise, but then sunk in it's formulaic fashion. The film was so long, and got stuck in places, I had to fast forward at times. A great premise, as I said, but then...Greg Kinnear plays a novelist, divorced but waiting for his ex-wife, played by Jennifeir Connolly to return. He has two children, Samantha, played by Lily Collins, a college student,who probably has the best bit of acting in this film, and Rusty, played by Nat Wolff, a high school student. Nat Wolff has a promising career ahead of him, fresh faced and winsome. Both children have been schooled to be writers as their dear old dad. Dad is very successful, and has the scraggly beard, sloppy look of a writer. Samantha is promiscuous and Nat is not. Dad is still waiting after three years for his ex-wife who has remarried to return.The scenery is beautiful, the acting leaves much to be desired, and the ending clenched the dislike of this film. I could have written this script, but I would be a little more clever.Not Recommended For Me. prisrob 01-11-14
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: The acting is fine, the story is interesting, and the characters are believable, but the movie just didn't move me.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: My wife and I watched this and both stayed involved.  We are in our late 40's and could relate.  Good humor as well.  Highly recommend

reviewText: I wasn't sure what to expect from this movie, it hadn't hit my radar previously.It was a little awkward at times, perhaps deliberately so, but it was mostly heartwarming and hopeful. Watch and feel good

reviewText: There's little to be offended by in this fill-in-the-blanks family dramedy. Greg Kinnear is appealing as always, and a phone-in cameo by Stephen King is a delight, as is an introduction to beer-can turkey. Jennifer Connelly is severely under-utilized here, but she is easy on the eyes. Other than, that, it's a well-acted by routine movie about a family of dysfunctional writers. Rent for a holiday family get together; it's a good way to nod off from turkey overdose.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: A  promising cast isn't able to inspire much interest in or sympathy for their broken characters, and the essential unreality and  contrivance of this dysfunctional  family as they limp toward a fairly pat denouement  makes it a cold and distant experience for this viewer.  It's not exactly a very romantic rom-com, nor is it especially funny, so what is it?  What they used to call  a "drawing room" movie, I suppose.There isn't much emotion that doesn't feel forced, not much sweep, and precious little spark. Kinnear is capable of more humor than this script gives him to work with, and his compulsion to reduce all life's experiences to story-fodder is creepy in its detachment from basic humanity; Connelly mopes and looks doleful most of the time, hardly a stretch for her abilities; Wolff plays stoned even when his character isn't; pretty Lily Collins may have the most screen time and at least looks like she *could* be Connelly's daughter (nice bit of casting there), but her character is relentlessly jaded, cynical, and emotionally retarded despite her surface breeziness and sass.  Other minor characters are cyphers, and with the exception of Lerman's nice-guy boyfriend wannabe,  it's very hard to feel close to any of them.  And there seems to be more than a little wish-fulfillment fantasizing going on with this film -- I mean,  writer-director Boone actually centers this movie around an entire FAMILY of writers -- not only is dad an admired author (who seems to be able to go two years without writing anything new and still afford a large beachhouse on the seashore), but his daughter (Collins) is on the verge of publishing her first book (destined to be a big hit, obviously), her love interest Lerman is a fellow writing student, and son Wolff is an aspiring poet/novelist.  None of them seem to have agents yet they are all living in the writers' dreamworld of instant fame, success, casual flings, and the avoidance of day jobs.  Oh, were this only the case.  Stephen King's cameo voiceover is especially beyond the beyonds ("Hey, I loved your story!" he tells Wolf over the phone) and he deserves to be pummeled with thousands of unsolicited manuscripts after this. I am wary of first-time director-writers like Boone, who regards this project as "his baby" and has drawn heavily from his own background for characters and incidents.  I can't help but feel some people ought to be in therapy working out their problems rather than inflicting them on the rest of us via the entertainment media. Maybe a moratorium should be proclaimed on the "Write what you know" approach, because we sure have way too many angst-ridden suburban-privilege stories being written and filmed by too many miserable well-off whiners.The usual heavy-handed soundtrack (oh, these tyrannical dictates to the iPod generation), with the standard ubiquitous and mostly dreary pop tunes, dominates and telegraphs, browbeating the viewer with "serious" moments, or "tender" moments, rather than the dialogue or the actors carrying these emotional peaks and valleys.  This lazy sonic shorthand is used as a crutch by far too many directors and producers and is a reason why so many of these movies wind up looking like long movie trailers or other commercials.  Despite being clearly told by the directors what and when to feel,  I never really cared about these characters, with their prickly personalities, their privilege (I don't know, maybe it's normal for today's high school  and college students to have plenty of money for clothes, cars, drugs, and not need to earn a mundane  living),  their lack of awareness, their sense of entitlement and immaturity, casual vulgarity, and empty souls.So beyond the problem of appealing to non non-struggling authors, are any of these people very engaging, interesting, or worth our involvement?  My feeling was, "No, not very."  The story takes the usual twists and turns, well signposted, to suggest stock character-building and formulaic development but it all comes across as forced or convenient.  Maybe there are too many plotlines to fit into a 90-minute movie -- many events seem rushed, and we never learn the fate of Rusty's girl, the troubled Kate, or how Dad disposes of his zipless-eff neighbor, or exactly what Erica has done to sever ties with her second husband -- but I was glad to reach the predictable end when it came, never mind putting up with another act.I must note the prominence here of short, two-line, nonsubstantive  glowing reviews. Is this another example of corporate promotion of products on Amazon by marketing agencies paying for sock puppets? Or is the audience for this movie about "Writers" unable to craft a review much beyond the 20-word minimum?  Gosh, writing IS hard work after all!
summary: Plodding melodrama is mostly Stuck in Neutral

Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Perhaps the movie deserves a 3 1/2 star rating...it was not wonderful, but it was now awful. The portrayal of a family of writers was romantic and shallow, but I enjoyed watching the cast do what they could with the material. Not bad. Not great..
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: I usually like rom coms and indie movies but this one somehow missed the mark. Probably because it wasn't the usual feel good happy ending sort of plot but more the message that if you really believe in true love they will cheat on you, die, or both. But if your cynical and don't believe that it's possible then somehow it just might work, sounds kind of a screwed up to me ! The acting for the most part was ok, but it felt like a very long 11/2 hours. The movie appeared to be searching for a heart and soul that it somehow just couldn't find. No comparison to some of the epic love stories like Love actually or Kate and Leopold which have much more sweetness and romance to them. In final analysis I'd agree with what other reviewers that said that it is watchable but forgettable.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Interesting story about a family of writers. The mother leaves the marriage and marries another man. The father still yearns for his wife. The older teenagers are caught up in their own discoveries about love. Very nice scenery and a movie well worth seeing if you believe in love.
summary: Authors unable to write the perfect love story

reviewText: Had a night to myself and decided to watch while the hubby was watching the tigers playoffs. I enjoyed it.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: "A writer is the sum of their experiences. Go get some." William Borgens (Kinnear) is a famous and best selling author who hasn't written anything since his wife left him three years ago. He is raising his two children who are also trying to become published. While his children are trying to figure their lives out William is stuck between trying to move on with his love life or keep waiting for his ex to return. This is a movie that I had high expectations for basically because I really like Greg Kinnear. This movie is very much like Crazy Stupid Love in tone so if you like that movie you will like this one as well. The acting in this is great as would be expected and this is a very real life type movie. Everyone in this is flawed but nothing to outrageous or unbelievable. That fact alone made the movie seem real and grounded. There really isn't much I can say without giving things away but I do recommend this and I did like it a lot. Overall, fans of Crazy Stupid Love will really like this. I give it a B.
summary: If you liked Crazy Stupid Love you will like this. Acting is great and the movie felt very real. I recommend this. I say B.
Title: Stuck in Love

reviewText: Even though I've never heard of this movie I'm glad we stumbled on it.  We both enjoyed all the top notch actors and the movie was just plain old sweet!
Title: Stuck in Love
